title: Proposal
text:
The source is the Cyber Operations Tracker by Council on Foreign Relations. This comprehensive database documents publicly acknowledged state-sponsored cyber incidents since 2005, cataloging over 500 cyber operations attributed to 34 countries. The data is compiled from open-source intelligence, such as government reports and media coverage.



The current data visualization is demonstrated in a simple 2D map format, which limits the ability to convey the complex, multi-dimensional nature of global cyber operations. We are proposing to develop a 3D globe visualization to:

Enhance spatial understanding of cyber attack patterns and geographic relationships
Provide intuitive interaction through rotation, zooming, and filtering capabilities
Display temporal evolution of cyber incidents through animated timelines
Improve user engagement with immersive visual storytelling

Beyond the visualization limitations, another critical issue with the original dataset is the ambiguity in its classification system for threat actors and victims. The current coding scheme relies heavily on agency-level attributions and organizational descriptors that often obscure the true nature of the actors involved. For instance, attacks may be attributed to specific intelligence agencies or military units rather than clearly identifying the sponsoring country, while victims are frequently categorized by sector or organization type without clear geographic or jurisdictional mapping. This lack of clarity makes it challenging to analyze patterns of state behavior, understand escalation dynamics, or identify targeting preferences.
To address this limitation, we will implement a more robust classification framework that:

Develops standardized victim categorization across geographic, sectoral, and criticality dimensions
Implements a multi-label system to capture complex agency levels and their relationships

This enhanced classification system will not only improve analytical accuracy but also enable more sophisticated visualizations.



The data production process will involve the following steps:

Data Cleaning and Standardization

Normalize country names and codes to ISO 3166-1 alpha-3 standards
Standardize date formats and handle missing temporal data

Data Structure Design

Restructure the data into proper format for temporal visualization and analysis
Convert the data into a format compatible with ArcGIS web applications
Design relational schema to store the various levels of data into a database

Data Enrichment

Concatenate with additional data

Other relational data such as alliances and conflicts
Other unit attribute level data such as technology capacity, etc.

Convert the cyber incidents into network object data for relational and geographic visualization
Use LLMs to extract information from the original source to create source level annotation

Data Visualization Design

Create ArcGIS app to visualize the data in 3D globe
Create a web app to integrate the geospatial visualization with other levels of data retrieval for user interaction





System Architecture:





%%{init: {'theme':'neutral', 'themeVariables': { 'primaryColor':'#fff','primaryTextColor':'#000','primaryBorderColor':'#000','lineColor':'#000','secondaryColor':'#fff','tertiaryColor':'#fff'}}}%%
flowchart TD
    subgraph Backend
        T1[cyber_operations]
        T2[country_attributes]
        T3[alliance_network]
        T4[conflict_network]
        DB[(Database)]
        
        T1 --> DB
        T2 --> DB
        T3 --> DB
        T4 --> DB
    end
    
    subgraph UI[User Interface]
        WEB[Web Application]
        ARC[ArcGIS App with Temporal Adjustment]
        NET[Network Graphs]
        MOD[Model Results Displays]
        
        WEB --> ARC
        WEB --> NET
        WEB --> MOD
    end
    
    DB --> WEB
    WEB --query--> DB
    ARC --query--> DB
    
    style Backend fill:none,stroke:#000
    style UI fill:#fff,stroke:#000






Visualization Components:

3D Globe (ArcGIS Web Scene): Interactive globe showing cyber operations with animated attack arcs between nations. Countries colored by incident frequency with height extrusion for attack intensity.
Temporal Slider: Timeline control to filter and animate cyber incidents across time periods. Playback functionality to observe attack pattern evolution.
Country Attributes Panel: Click on nations to display: cyber capabilities proxy, alliance memberships, conflict relationships, historical incident counts etc.
Social Network Graph: Directed graph where nodes represent nations (sized by cyber capability, color and shape indicating other attributes) and edges show cyber operations (thickness indicating frequency).
Model Results Displays:

Spatial Interaction Model: Flow map with chord diagram showing bilateral cyber attacks flows, highlighting geospatial proximity effects with thicker arcs
STOAT Outputs: Temporal multiplex network with time steps as layers, shown in two panels for international relations networks (alliances and conflicts) and cyber incident networks ### Data Analysis Planning


We intend to leverage the geospatial and temporal network analysis to extract meaningful insights from the data.
Geospatial Analysis: 1. Implement a Spatial Interaction Model based on gravity theory to analyze cyber operations between countries (PySAL spint). This model uses the following predictors to estimate cyber incident outcomes: the cyber capabilities of both the sponsoring and victim countries, the alliance and conflict relationships between them, and whether they share a land border. The model will leverage geospatial information to test whether border contiguity increases cyber operations when countries are in conflict, capturing how regional tensions and conflicts are coordinated in cyberspace, such as the cyber operations between Ukraine and Russia representing a modern “hybrid warfare” in both cyberspace and physical space.
Temporal Network Inference: 2. Implement STOAT (Spatial-Temporal Probabilistic Causal Inference Network) for cyber operations (arXiv:2506.09544). This method performs causal inference by incorporating a spatial relation matrix that encodes interregional dependencies between nations, but instead of geographic proximity we use international relations connectivity (alliances, conflicts, technology partnerships). This enables spatially informed causal effect estimation where cyber operations propagate through international relations networks rather than physical space contingencies or proximity.

title: Competition 2
text:
owideu$date = as.Date(owideu$date)

png("c2p1.png", width = 1200, height = 600)

plot(owideu$date, owideu$new_deaths, 
     pch = 16, 
     cex = 0.5, 
     col = "#E91E63",
     xlab = "Date", 
     ylab = "COVID Deaths in Europe (Daily)",
     main = "",
     xlim = as.Date(c("2020-01-01", "2023-08-31")),
     ylim = c(0, max(owideu$new_deaths, na.rm = TRUE)),
     xaxt = "n",
     bty = "o")

axis.Date(1, at = seq(as.Date("2020-01-01"), as.Date("2023-08-31"), by = "2 months"),
          format = "%Y-%m", las = 2, cex.axis = 0.7)

df_labels = data.frame(
  country = c("Germany", "Spain", "Ukraine", "Italy"),
  stringsAsFactors = FALSE
)

for(country_name in df_labels$country) {
  df_country = owideu[owideu$location == country_name, ]
  if(nrow(df_country) > 0 && any(!is.na(df_country$new_deaths))) {
    idx_max = which.max(df_country$new_deaths)
    if(length(idx_max) > 0) {
      text(df_country$date[idx_max], df_country$new_deaths[idx_max], 
           labels = country_name, pos = 3, cex = 0.8)
    }
  }
}

invisible(dev.off())

title: Competition 2
text:
owideu$date = as.Date(owideu$date)

png("c2p1.png", width = 1200, height = 600)

plot(owideu$date, owideu$new_deaths, 
     pch = 16, 
     cex = 0.5, 
     col = "#E91E63",
     xlab = "Date", 
     ylab = "COVID Deaths in Europe (Daily)",
     main = "",
     xlim = as.Date(c("2020-01-01", "2023-08-31")),
     ylim = c(0, max(owideu$new_deaths, na.rm = TRUE)),
     xaxt = "n",
     bty = "o")

axis.Date(1, at = seq(as.Date("2020-01-01"), as.Date("2023-08-31"), by = "2 months"),
          format = "%Y-%m", las = 2, cex.axis = 0.7)

df_labels = data.frame(
  country = c("Germany", "Spain", "Ukraine", "Italy"),
  stringsAsFactors = FALSE
)

for(country_name in df_labels$country) {
  df_country = owideu[owideu$location == country_name, ]
  if(nrow(df_country) > 0 && any(!is.na(df_country$new_deaths))) {
    idx_max = which.max(df_country$new_deaths)
    if(length(idx_max) > 0) {
      text(df_country$date[idx_max], df_country$new_deaths[idx_max], 
           labels = country_name, pos = 3, cex = 0.8)
    }
  }
}

invisible(dev.off())

title: My Quarto Website
text:
materials

a final table, unit being victim
scraped pdfs arranged by working progress
4 out of 5 regions are annotated



expectation

to establish the relation between table records and saved pdfs
cleaned up corpus for finetuning



current status

rearranged the table to be victim-source, for better linkage between record and files
populated the last region and merge with the final table
rearranged the pdfs in region/victim structure rather than working progress
rescraped lost files, so that 80% of the victim-sources are recovered, having correct files linking to the records
preliminary cleaning of the pdfs show reference files here



issues

original table unit is not suitable for buiding record-file relation (solved)
files are not structured in a way that can be easily tracked (solved)
pdfs cannot be linked back to records (solved)
lost files (recovered partially)
one region is not annotated (not solved)
pdfs contains content that are not related to the topic, such as ads, comments, placeholders. (not solved. Docling and olmocr can only identify some of them and no 100% guarantee) add examples here



what could have done differently

rescrape everthing at the beginning will save massive time. Reverse engineering is more costly than having a clean start



future steps and options

get clean text files


option 1. select and pick the “cleaner” pdfs

pro:

files are readily available

con:

only a very small fraction of the file will be used.
picking out “cleaner” files may take unknown time, and may need manual labor.


option 2. rescrape all available links and save into html.

pro:

a clean start
more files
timeline is more controlable

con:

some links might be broken




cleaning

if using only the “cleaner” pdfs, docling should do the job, if these pdfs are guaranteed to be “cleaner”.
if taking the total rescraping route, select correct elements from the htmls.

fine-tuning

use shreyas pipeline, show reference
